chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This book is out to rectify injustices done from impure speech; particularly in the usage of the categories of non-Jews within Jewish Law: the Torah. This book will help to re-humanize the non-Jew within the Torah by clarifying proper terms used for non-Jews and their respective laws that unfortunately get convoluted and overlooked. There is a vicious cycle of de-humanization between the Jew and non-Jew that can be stopped by using pure speech and logical application of that speech to proper definitions within Torah. Torah has never been the problem. Rather, misunderstandings of different types of non-Jews is the main problem in this regard. Many today don't even realize there are different types of non-Jews in Torah, each with their own treatment. Specifically, this book is about subsets of non-Jews, their critical definitions, and Torah law pertaining to their respective non-Jew subsets. These subsets are either entirely mutually exclusive, or have only some exclusivity in respect to their properties. For instance, all humans have chromosomes, but not all humans keep kosher; so the subsets are defined in respect to the properties wrote about in this book. This book is about specific subsets of non-Jews and their respective properties. These subsets or categories, are called gedarim in Hebrew.

Once the reader sees the different gedarim gedarim of non-Jews within Torah using their proper Hebrew nouns as described in this book, the reader will be able to see the improper usage of terms about the different non-Jews and how such terms lead to misunderstanding and misapplication of Torah law, foundational misquotes used for antisemitism, etc. An example, is a translation and misquote of a major redactor of Jewish Law known as the R"AMBAM which says in his Mishneh Torah that a non-Jew who involves himself in Torah study is obligated to die.
R"AMBAM, Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Melachim 10:9 Such a translation and misquote that depicts all non-Jews not only sounds horrible, it's actually wrong. In reality, as I shall prove in this book, the verse in the original Hebrew is describing wicked non-Jews, who for the most part in our western culture today, don't exist. Unfortunately, the aforementioned translation is the common translation of such verses of Torah law pertaining to non-Jews. Such translations and traditions about the non-Jew promulgate within the unlearned Jewish community and eventually end up in the non-Jewish community where the damage comes full circle. Thankfully, with proper understanding, this grave misunderstanding can be remedied. With this book, I hope to bring to light this proper understanding and will help usher in the true view of Torah being a pleasant and peaceful path.
"Her ways are pleasant ways, and all her paths are peace." - Proverbs 3:17

Gedarim have certain properties associated with them. For instance, let's look at the word goy. The geder for goy has a legal status such that a goy that gives tzedakah/charity to bnei Yisrael/a child of Israel(colloquially: a Jew): bnei Yisrael cannot benefit from that tzedakah and the tzedakah must be given instead to the goy poor. However, when a ben Noach/a child of Noah(which is under a different geder than goy) gives charity to bnei Yisrael, the poor of bnei Yisrael can use that tzedakah. Even more so, Yisrael has a mitzvah/commandment to save the life of a ben Noach in trouble, while bnei Yisrael have no such mitzvah to save the life of a goy. Even more so, bnei Yisrael are obligated to not save a goy from death. So then, one must ask: What is a goy? What is a ben Noach? Why are they treated differently?

These different categories of non-Jews will be explained in this book. This book will properly show some correct definitions and differences of these gedarim of non-Jews, which will expose many horrible translations or misunderstandings about quotes of Torah. This book will help break the vicious cycle of ignorance by bringing back purity of language, which will help bring pleasantness and peace.
"For then I will restore to the peoples a pure language, That they all may call on haShem, To serve Him with one accord." - Zephaniah 3:9 The R"AMBAM in his Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Melachim 10:10, shows a good example of two different gedarim.
"A ben Noach that wants to do a mitzvah/commandment from the other mitzvot of the Torah(beyond the seven of bnei Noach) in order to receive reward, [Yisrael] does not keep him from doing it properly. And if he brings a burnt offering, we receive it. If he gives tzedakah, we receive it from him and it appears to me that it is given to the poor of Yisrael. He receives his sustenance from Yisrael and it is a mitzvah to sustain his life. However, the goy that gives tzedakah, we receive it and give it to the poor goyim" - R"AMBAM, Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Melachim 10:10 Many will tell you that the goy and the ben Noach are the same thing: that they're all the gentile or the non-Jew in Torah; this is often how goy is erroneously translated from the Hebrew into "gentile". However, as one can see, they are not the same. There is some mutual exclusivity, as we just read, between the goy and the ben Noach who gives tzedakah. Even though both goy and ben Noach are in the set of non-Jews, they are their own respective subset with their own respective properties and dinim/laws. These sets or categories are called gedarim and it is these sets and their respective properties which is what this book is about. Before we get into the different gedarim, let's first learn a few definitions that are mandatory for this book.

sect1.title: Ikkar
sect1.para: Ikkar is the Hebrew term for concept or principal. In the southern United States, people say, "Bless his heart..." in regards to someone who tries to do right, but often fails by his or her own fault. "Bless his heart..." is an ikkar term. The phrase has meaning more than just the sum of it's parts, as it relates a concept. The Torah has it's own ikkar terms that carry the same meaning from context to context, creating a continuity between these contexts that would otherwise seemingly not exist. Ikkar terms such as Umot haOlam/People of the World, Chasidei Umot haOlam/Pious people of the World, Am haAretz/people of the land, are used throughout this book.

sect1.title: Klipah
sect1.para:
We first need to talk about souls and where they emanate from. Klipah klipah is the Hebrew word for shell; a shell or rind of a fruit, for instance. Just as klipah blocks one from getting to the good fruit inside, so too, klipah blocks Godliness from being seen in this world. There are four major kinds of klipah. There are three completely impure and opaque klipot called klipat tameyut that does not allow any Godliness to shine through it. There is a fourth klipah which is a mixture of pure and impure called klipat nogah, which is an illuminating shell.
Tanya, Ch. 1 It is not opaque, but translucent and allows Godliness to shine through it.

Every living thing with blood in its body has an animal soul called a nefesh behemut and every human being has an additional Godly soul called a nefesh Elokit. The nefesh behamut emanates from the klipot. The nefesh Elokit is truly a part of haShem. Everyone can detect their nefesh behemut, but not everyone can detect, or is ruled by, their nefesh Elokit. All nefeshot behemut emanate from some type of klipah depending on what type of nefesh behemut it has. Unlike the nefesh behemut that emanates from klipah, the nefesh Elokit emanates completely, and is directly a part of, haShem.

While there is only one nefesh Elokit, there are two major kinds of nefashot behemot. Umot haOlam have nefashot behemot that emanate from the three, completely impure, klipot tameyut. Because Umot haOlam emanate from the completely impure klipat tameyut, people that have these animal souls do not detect Godliness on their own and therefore are seemingly completely removed from their nefesh Elokit/Godly soul.

All human beings have a Godly soul called a nefesh Elokit. The nefesh Elokit is completely concealed in the Umot haOlam from their perspective. It hovers over them and is distant from them as what is called makif rachok.
Ginsburgh, Kabbalah and Meditation for the Nations, page 55-56
